Dated this the 01* day of August, 2016
ORDER
The petitioners herein are the accused in C.P
No.42 of 2003 of Judicial First Class Magistrate Court,
Perinthalmanna. The aforesaid case had arisen from
Crime No. 346 of 2002 of Perinthalmanna Police Station
registered alleging offences punishable under Sections
143, 147, 148, 447, 341, 323, 324, 307 read with
Sec.149 of the Indian Penal Code.

2. After investigation, the final report was laid
before the jurisdictional Magistrate against the petitioners
and 21 others. The petitioners were the accused Nos. 4
and 15 in the final report. The petitioners were not
available for committal and the case against others were
committed before the Court of Sessions. The trial was
proceeded with against the aforesaid case and as per
Annexure-B judgment dated 24.03.2007, all the other
accused except the petitioners and accused No.3 were
acquitted under Section 232 of the Code of Criminal

eee
2016/KER/33668

Crl.M.C.No. 4678 of 2016 ;

Procedure. Thereafter, the 3 accused surrendered before
the learned Sessions Judge and the case against him was
proceeded with in S.C No. 42 of 2008 and by Annexure-C
judgment dated 17.04.2008, he was also found not guilty
of the offences alleged against him and was liable to be
acquitted.

3. The learned counsel appearing for the
petitioners submits that in view of Annexure B and C
judgments of the learned Sessions Judge, the substratum
of case against the petitioners have been shattered. I
have bestowed my _-— anxious’- considerations and
submissions and have perused Annexures B and C
judgments of the learned Sessions Judge. From para
No.7 of Annexure-B judgment, it is discernible that the
presence of some of the material witnesses could not be
secured in spite of initiating coercive steps. PWs 1 to 4
did not support the prosecution case. Annexure-C
judgment also tells the same story.

eee
2016/KER/33668
Crl.M.C.No. 4678 of 2016 3

4. In Moosa v. Sub Inspector of Police (2006
(1) KLT 552) a Full Bench of this Court had occasion to
hold that though the judgment rendered in the case of a
co-accused and the reasoning of the judgment contained
therein or appreciation of the evidence therein are not
matters to be taken into account for the purpose of
granting any relief to quash the proceedings and thus bar
the trial itself, a case wherein the very substratum of the
case is lost may be an exception to this rule. The same
view was followed in the precedents cited supra.

5. I am of the firm view that no purpose is going to
be served by directing the petitioners to face the trial at
this stage. It can only be a futile exercise and the only
purpose that will be served is to gnaw into precious time
during which more productive work can be done by the
court below. The prospects of conviction is extremely
remote owing to the acquittal of the co accused.

In the result this petition is allowed and all
further proceedings against the petitioners in C.P No.42
